text: Thanks <@U0107Q25BRT>! That’s more in line with what I would have expected. I have a developer friend at Google and he was saying if I keep going with my Head of Content / Documentation role, down the line, I could eventually be earning $250K USD (or even $500K as a manager) at Google. But I haven’t found anything to validate those numbers. What I’ve found on Glassdoor more or less aligns with what you’re saying here.

elements.text: ! That’s more in line with what I would have expected. I have a developer friend at Google and he was saying if I keep going with my Head of Content / Documentation role, down the line, I could eventually be earning $250K USD (or even $500K as a manager) at Google. But I haven’t found anything to validate those numbers. What I’ve found on Glassdoor more or less aligns with what you’re saying here.

text:
<@U01BQ274GN7> No problem! To be honest with any company, job titles don't mean much alone when looking at compensation. It's important to look at the responsibilities. $250k-$500k is what data scientists and engineering managers make. For marketing, I'd say $200k+ is realistic for a Director level role or CMO, or VP of marketing  where you're managing budgets and direct reports.

If you don't want to have direct reports (a route I've been going) I'd say $120k-$150k is the norm. The main thing isn't necessarily the amount of people you manage but rather the responsibilities you have. In my roles I've done a lot of interfacing with contractors instead of direct reports. That's usually a great way to build up responsibilities and climb the ladder a bit without going all in on being a people manager.

elements.text:
No problem! To be honest with any company, job titles don't mean much alone when looking at compensation. It's important to look at the responsibilities. $250k-$500k is what data scientists and engineering managers make. For marketing, I'd say $200k+ is realistic for a Director level role or CMO, or VP of marketing  where you're managing budgets and direct reports.

If you don't want to have direct reports (a route I've been going) I'd say $120k-$150k is the norm. The main thing isn't necessarily the amount of people you manage but rather the responsibilities you have. In my roles I've done a lot of interfacing with contractors instead of direct reports. That's usually a great way to build up responsibilities and climb the ladder a bit without going all in on being a people manager.
